\pagebreak{}


\section{Introduction}

open-innovation-projects.org (\emph{OIP} in the text following) lists
mostly OSHW projects and systematically categorizes them. Out of the
\textsubscript{\textasciitilde{}}150 listed entries, the following
109 retained our attention in the context of OSHWL (those that previously
weren't mentioned in OSHWL were subsequently added to it):

We will also apply the same ``standardized'' categorization effort
to the following OSHWL projects, not listed by OIP (\tabref{OSHWL-projects-categorized}):

\begin{table}[H]
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}

\caption{other OSHWL projects categorized according to OIP's method\label{tab:OSHWL-projects-categorized}}
\end{table}
\pagebreak{}

The following is the categorization itself (in tables making overview
and comparison easy, as opposed to individual project sheets as is
the case on open-innovation-projects.org), copied from OIP for the
projects they list and complemented with the projects from \tabref{OSHWL-projects-categorized}.

There are three groups of criteria:
\begin{itemize}
\item project details
\item product details
\item institutional design and production
\end{itemize}

\section{Project details}

First, a description of the categories in the tables directly following.


\paragraph{project type}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{single\ project\hspace{3.3em}}] \noindent one or more specific
product(s) is/are shown and/or developed 
\item [{collection\ of\ projects}] overview over several different projects
or product, e.g. OIP itself
\end{lyxlist}

\paragraph{development Status}

current stage of development according to the following:
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{1}] planning/virtual development - ideas and digital dev. evolving 
\item [{2}] prototyping started - first physical proto. assembled, testing
phase 
\item [{3}] first working proto. - working proto. available, release to
community, further dev. needed 
\item [{4}] production stable - fully functional product permanently available
on market, further dev. possible 
\item [{5}] mature - final dev. stage reached, no further dev. necessary 
\item [{Inactive}] dev. stopped, no final product available
\end{lyxlist}
in case several products are being developed, the stage of the most
advanced product is indicated. 


\paragraph{license and trademark}
\begin{itemize}
\item whether the project is using an open license and of which type
\item whether they have a registered trademark
\end{itemize}

\paragraph{country}

main location, i.e. home country of the project leader, the core team
or the office location. 


\paragraph{start year}

year in which the project was initiated.

\vfill{}

\pagebreak{}


\section{Product details}

First, a description of the categories in the tables directly following.


\paragraph*{product innovativeness}

degree of innovativeness according to the following criteria: 
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{5}] radical innovation - a new technology that results in a new
market infrastructure, e.g. an innovation which does not address a
recognized demand but instead creates a demand previously unrecognized
by the consumer 
\item [{4}] really new innovation - a really new product results in a market
discontinuity or a technological discontinuity but will not incorporate
both, e.g., new product lines, product line extensions with new technology,
or new markets with existing technology 
\item [{3}] discontinous innovations - new technologies that don't lead
to discontinuity in existing markets 
\item [{2}] incremental innovations - products that provide new features,
benefits, or improvements to the existing technology in the existing
market 
\item [{1}] imitative innovations - imitative products are frequently new
to the firm, but not new to the market 
\end{lyxlist}

\paragraph*{product complexity}

degree of complexity for the developed product ranging between the
following:
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{1}] low complexity, e.g. a simple wooden chair
\item [{...}]~
\item [{5}] high complexity, e.g. an aircraft or a nuclear power plant
\end{lyxlist}

\paragraph*{industry}

suitable industry from a list given by OIP. \vfill{}

\pagebreak{}


\section{Institutional design and production}

First, a description of the categories in the table directly following.


\paragraph*{contribution}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{user}] whether private persons or users are actively involved in
the development. 
\item [{commercial}] whether commercial companies are actively involved
in the development. 
\item [{research}] whether research institutions are actively involved
in the development. 
\end{lyxlist}

\paragraph*{type of collaboration}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{\emph{collective\ development\ of...}}]~

\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{\emph{one}{\small \ }\emph{common}{\small \ }\emph{product}}] if
a community is commonly developing one product. 
\item [{\emph{several}{\small \ }\emph{common}{\small \ }\emph{products}}] if
a community is commonly developing several different products. 
\end{lyxlist}
\item [{\emph{published\ knowledge...}}]~

\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{\emph{with}{\small \ }\emph{some}{\small \ }\emph{coll}{\small .\ }\emph{dev.}}] if
instructions or ideas are published and others make comments and suggestions. 
\item [{\emph{without}{\small \ }\emph{collective}{\small \ }\emph{dev.}}] if
information is purely revealed. 
\end{lyxlist}
\end{lyxlist}

\paragraph*{degree of openness (radicalized from OIP's version) / entirety of
openness}

Whether or not the project is revealing all available information. 


\paragraph*{production}

entity responsible for production. ``related company or assoc.''
refers to an entity closely related to the project or with a production
mandate. \textquotedbl{}outsourced\textquotedbl{} is whenever an external
party is paid for supplying components. 

\vfill{}
